s1: Paying higher prices helps developing countries make better trading conditions and promotes sustainability
s2: In order to make goods cheap, they need to be made somewhere with a cheaper labour force.

s1: Protect the services and resources that the Government looks after, they will be worth more in the long term.
s2: Sell things that belong to the Government to businesses for a quick profit.

s1: Free education from the Goverment, where everyone has equal opportunities. The most important thing is to ask questions.
s2: It's up to the individual to get educated, not the Government. The most important thing is to succeed at whatever you study.

s1: Power should come from renewable resources. Research into future possibilities for different technology.
s2: Keep the current power system going and maintain stability, while looking for natural resources to use as energy.

s1: Keep NZ Nuclear Free
s2: Cancel the ban on nuclear powered ships from NZ waters.

s1: The natural environment is fragile and precious, we shouldn't tamper with it or abuse it.
s2: In order to grow the economy, it means exporting resources from the natural environment.

s1: Diplomacy based on mutual respect and trust is the best way to approach relations with other nations.
s2: Develop relationships with key nations for mutual economic, military and political interests.

s1: Healing should be about getting the whole person well and making sure they're safe at home and work. The Government should pick up the bill.
s2: Treatment should just be about the problem. Hospitals should be efficient at getting patients out to make room for others. Make Private hospitals an option for those who can afford.

s1: Increasing government funded housing plans. Focusing on community growth.
s2: Focusing on housing legislation reforms and development of urban areas.

s1: People should be able to receive monetary support from the Government through taxes to help those who need it.
s2: People should be self-reliant and beneficiaries should educate themselves and get skills to re-renter the workforce.

s1: Genetic technology is ok as long as it's kept in the lab and not in the food chain. Science can be used to explain the future.
s2: It's ok for businesses to use technology for commercial gain. Science is most useful to explain the past.

s1: In order to serve everyone, laws can be changed to alter the way people live. Helping those with the smallest voice.
s2: No-one should be able to interfere with my private life. Laws are there to maintain order.

s1: Criminals are products of their environments. Prison should be about treatment and getting them back into society.
s2: People become criminals because they want to be, and they should be punished.

s1: NZ is a political, cultural and religious sanctuary for all, there should be no discrimination.
s2: Skilled migrants are the most useful ones, we shouldn't let too many people into the country because there won't be enough jobs.

s1: The Internet should be available to everybody. Allowing more business competition means lower costs.
s2: The Internet is potentially a dangerous breeding ground for social disharmony and Terrorism. A monopoly on Internet provision means stability.

s1: Employees are the workforce of the economy, they deserve to be paid fairly and protected by law.
s2: Employers run the businesses that keep the economy growing, they should have just as much rights as employees.

s1: Public transport is important because there will be less environmental impact and it should be cheaper.
s2: Private cars mean mobility and efficiency.

s1: Tax the top earners and keep an eye on businesses so taxes can be distributed to the public through Government programs.
s2: Businesses that are doing well financially should not be tampered with. Taxes should be easy for everyone.

s1: We should be open to renewing our stance on nuclear technology if it benefits our relationships abroad.
s2: Keep New Zealand nuclear free.

s1: The Treaty of Waitangi (Te Tiriti o Waitangi) is a historical document that doesn't have much relevance to today's issues.
s2: The Treaty of Waitangi (Te Tiriti o Waitangi) is a very important document which should guide the government. It is still important to correct past wrongs.

s1: Investing time and money into the Arts, our Film Industry and our heritage buildings protects our history and adds to the social, cultural and economic fabric of New Zealand.
s2: We should be more future-minded about our buildings and culture. The Arts and Film Industry won't add much value to the New Zealand economy.

s1: Sport can be a big money earner, it's important to New Zealand culture and participation in sporting activities should be encouraged.
s2: With obesity and other health problems affecting kiwis, government funding for professional athletes could be better spent elsewhere.

s1: Te Reo is an important language to New Zealand culture, everyone should have the opportunity to learn and speak it.
s2: There is no commercial benefit to learning Te Reo, schooling should focus on a diverse range of language skills to reflect New Zealand's diversity.

s1: Tourism is a cornerstone industry in New Zealand. Advertising plays a crucial role and the government must do whatever it takes to maintain a 'clean, green' image to the world.
s2: It is not worthwhile pursuing a 'green' image, we should be investing into other sources of income. Bio-security is difficult to maintain.

s1: Community support and funding for USAR and emergency services are vital, the most important consideration for natural disasters and emergencies is preparation.
s2: The Earthquake Commission and governmental relationships with Insurance Companies are vital because the most important consideration for natural disasters and emergencies is the response.
